thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: El Toro motor inn sold for $24m
thread.title_full: El Toro motor inn sold for $24m

title: El Toro motor inn sold for $24m
text:
The El Toro Motor Inn Hotel, Liverpool, at 4-6 Homepride Avenue, Warwick Farm.
In further evidence that investors prefer bricks and mortar to the volatile sharemarket, a private family has paid $24 million for the El Toro Motor Inn Hotel, Liverpool.
JLL Hotels & Hospitality group sold the property on behalf of the listed Lantern Hotel Group, with the funds being ploughed back into the business.
The sale comes as more than $100 million of pubs and hotels have changed hands in the past six months, ranging from suburban sites at the Northern beaches, and from Paddington to Liverpool.
Agents said demand was rising for the fringe hotels, as investors steer clear of City venues that have been impacted by the new drinking lock out regulations.
Advertisement The El Toro Motor Inn includes 29 gaming machines, 55 motel rooms and occupies a 1.4 hectare site area in the heart of Liverpool's burgeoning development precinct.
In a short statement to the ASX, Lantern's executive director, Russell Naylor, said the price is a premium to the hotel's December 2014 carrying value, and will increase net asset value per security (before costs) from 11.5cps to 12.4cps (based on Lantern's 31 December 2014 carrying value and balance sheet adjusted for the sale of the Five Dock bottleshop land which settled in June this year).
The hotel's selling agent John Musca, national Director, investment sales, said the transaction represented an attractive premium to carrying value for the vendors and offered exciting trade growth and large-scale redevelopment potential for the purchasers.
"The transaction follows the recent sale of the Macquarie Hotel in the Liverpool CBD for $25 million, also sold by JLL, further evidencing the market engagement with the Liverpool growth story as NSW's designated third city and earmarked for circa 500,000 square metres of additional commercial and retail development," Mr Musca said.
"With a significant trading history as a consistent Top 100 gaming hotel, El Toro principally delivers a substantial underlying holding income on what is effectively a strategic greenfield future redevelopment site, ideally optimised by private hoteliers with a long term view." One of the recent sales was by the The Bayfield family, who bought the popular Sydney pub the Light Brigade Hotel in Paddington.
Agents to the sale, Ray White Hotels' Asia Pacific managing director Andrew Jolliffe and associate director Joel Fisher, said no price was disclosed. However, other similar freehold pubs in the area, such as the Grand National, have changed hands at between $7 to $9 million in the past few months.
